comments.course: cool assignments, interesting subject matter. would recommend.
comments.professor: balkcom is probably the best CS prof. very clear lectures, very laid back and approachable guy.
comments.workload:
Like any CS course, you gotta stay on top of the coding exercises. That said, for me they were sort of a breeze. I'm super comfy with python and with coding in general. i consistently finished the projects a few days ahead of time, but i also had no life that quarter.

also, no exams or even any sort of final. just a coding assignment every week. cool stuff.

comments.course: Went over big concepts in macroeconomics.  Its a major course, so you're probably going to take it because of that.
comments.professor: Professor was knowledgeable, and pretty fair.
comments.workload: Not a bad workload at all.  A couple problem sets not graded on correctness, but effort.  2 midterms and a final

comments.course: Very interesting course.  Lots of guests who are knowledgeable about their instruments and cultural music.  Lots of movie clips and discussions.  Great class!  You definitely should take this!
comments.professor: Great professor, very knowledgeable, very fair.  Loves his subject, and you can tell.
comments.workload: Not that much work at all, just a couple very short papers and attending 2 concerts outside of class.

comments.course: Very interesting course.  As somebody who knew nothing about the financial world, this course gave insight into how financial intermediaries and markets work.
comments.professor: Very knowledgeable professor, teaches by the socratic method, which is really useful.  Does not make fun of you if you get a question wrong, just is interested in making sure students know the right answers.
comments.workload: Pretty much a chapter and a problem set a class.  He encourages you to work in groups, and you definitely need to.  Meet before every class to go over the questions.  The exams are not that hard, and he gives you a lot of practice tests.

comments.course: Not many people think this course ranks high interest-wise in the econ department, but it is a necessary course.
comments.professor: Makes the course as interesting as can be.  Explains concepts well
comments.workload: Not that much work, just a problem set a week, and 2 midterms and a final.  Powerpoint slides are posted online, and those are pretty much all you have to study for the exams

comments.course: I wasn't particularly engaged by the course material, but I think that was personal preference. It was organized chronologically on the geologic time scale, and it matched the description well.
comments.professor: I missed a lot of class for athletic competition, and the prof was super understanding and really helpful. However, he was trying out a new attendance policy that killed me. His lectures were awesome; super detailed, clear. I felt well prepared for the exams and I didn't do any of the readings.
comments.workload: Evenly spaced assignments and quizzes, knew what to expect. Assignments were hands on, but not too difficult, especially if you have an aptitude for this kind of open ended thinking characteristic of the earth's history...

comments.course: It wasn't really a writing course, which was fine by me... We did 3 essays but didn't focus on writing at all. Lectures were about random stuff in the solar system and research the prof had done on micrometeorites. About half of what we learned I used in an essay.
comments.professor: It was cool how much experience she had in research. It made me realize that the people here are/have been on the cutting edge. She didn't give much feedback for my writing style though.
comments.workload: I didn't think assignments were spaced well. We had periods where we were doing nothing followed by a 20 hour week... The first essay was short and relatively easy, the research paper was long, and the last paper was an extremely specific wiki on micrometeorites, which was super hard because there's very little research available on them!

comments.course: I definitely felt like it served its purpose as a writing course, without being overwhelmingly focused on writing. We had a wide variety of assignments, from group projects to short casual responses to formal essays to journal entries. We presented a couple orally. Always had enough time for the assignments. I got the feeling that there was a bigger task of the class than to teach us to write.
comments.professor: Class was always intriguing and exciting. Prof O seemed like it was his goal to give us a life lesson, not just a writing class. His passion for the themes of the book we read (things like mindfulness and self introspection) was perfect for me, and I liked the idea that what we were doing was just a class, but what we were learning could be applied to so much more. We did mindfulness exercises and meditations, and we even covered a bit of environmentalism.
comments.workload: Evenly spaced, manageable. Tasks were clear, suggestions for improvement were helpful, option to revise was useful.

comments.course: So fun, great intro to the language and culture.
comments.professor: Prof Viazmenski was exciting, happy, and very understanding. I had a challenging schedule and she really was accommodating. Lectures and readings went together well.
comments.workload: A couple pages of reading per night, evenly spaced exams, weekly assignments (I spent maybe an hour a week on them), and one final project on a topic of our choice. Easy, effective, engaging.

comments.course: Rise of China by Lind - a great comprehensive look into China and Asian politics overall. I had no Chinese background in this class, but came out feeling like I could have a solid debate and good understanding of China's position and prospects in the world.
comments.professor: Professor Lind is a specialist in North Korea and Japan, not China, so she wasn't able to give us a huge amount of extra knowledge about China outside of our readings, but her international relations background helped a lot to put China in context. Does a great job fostering class discussion.
comments.workload: Lots of reading, which you should be able to discuss in class. A midterm paper and a written identify concepts/essay final. Enough to keep you busy, but the reading is interesting.

comments.course: Very interesting intro to foreign policy and US history of foreign policy.
comments.professor: Strathman is a hugely knowledgable and engaging lecturer, as well as being very approachable in and out of class.
comments.workload: Lots of reading (some more interesting than others), and midterm/exams with identifying concepts and short essays. Also a final paper on the topic of your choosing.

comments.course: I placed out of this course but didn't feel like I understood the material. I am super interested in math but not very good at it, so I hoped this class would help me gain a deep understanding of calc. It didn't... I found lectures to not be helpful at all, since the group was far to big to ask one-on-one questions when I was confused (which was often). Office hours were extremely busy. The tutorials were what saved me. The grad students were so helpful. For me it was all about finding the right person whose mind thought about math the way mine does.
comments.professor: It was clear she knew what she was doing, and she told a lot of fun analogies to help us understand, but the style of teaching was something like: let me tell you how to do something and why it works, and then tell you what it is we're actually doing. I'd done the stuff before, taken an AP test on it, and couldn't figure out what we were trying to do! I wish she'd told us our objective, then taught us how to do it. Also, her office hours were not helpful. They were so short, and always too crowded to be helpful.
comments.workload: Same every week; online problem sets, didn't vary much. Grading system was ok, seemed like I got the points I deserved, sometimes I felt like I did better than I deserved. You could also get a little ahead if you wanted. Tests were evenly spaced and I always knew what was going to be on them.

comments.course: Interesting material, well-paced.
comments.professor: Irwin was super nice and approachable, though sometimes he made explaining things more complicated than they need to be.
comments.workload: Workload is quite easy - the only thing you need to read is his textbook and a few extra assigned readings, and he covers most of it in class. Nevertheless, the midterms/exam were tricky.

comments.course: It was interesting and there was a lot of reading, but it was really easy.
comments.professor: His lectures can be pretty dry and are exactly like the readings, but they were somewhat interesting and he is really laid back and tries to make it interesting and easy.
comments.workload: There was a lot of reading, but not much else, the paper wasn't that bad and neither were either of the exams

comments.course: This course was incredibly fast paced and also really intense. It was a huge amount of work with so many readings every class and you have to do them since it is such a small class you have to do all of the readings. The final project was huge and using Stata was a requirement, which was very hard to do since she didn't teach much about it.
comments.professor: She knew a lot about the material. She is really nice and wants everyone to do well

comments.course: Really interesting course if you are willing to put in the time. You cover the entire text book cover-to-cover. Most of the learning is done on your own. You prep questions for class, are cold called during class, and expect to know the answers
comments.professor:
God mode. Awesome professor, really interested in the subject and thrilled to be teaching. He spent 20yrs on Wall St. as a chief economist - the guy knows his stuff. Lot of fun and very interesting to talk to. Definitely go ask him questions in office hours.

Totally gets Dartmouth life too, son was a Dartmouth '09.
comments.workload: More work than you'll do for any other Econ class. Entirely worth it, but it can be 3-6hrs of prep for every class.

comments.course: The course was great because I like jazz. It was pretty much just sitting in class, listening to Jazz greats, and watching a few videos. If anything, it might've been a little slow, but it was relaxing and enjoyable. If you like Jazz, definitely take this course. If not, read below (workload).
comments.professor: Haas's voice lulls you to sleep pretty easily, but since you're falling asleep to Jazz, it's not so bad. He's a really chill guy that knows a ton about Jazz music, and sometimes he bring out his sax or sits at the piano to play ridiculously well.
comments.workload: The workload for this course was unbelievably easy. There is supposedly nightly reading, but I didn't know about them until a month into the term, and never had to do them. There are 2 quizzes, a midterm, and a final, which all require that you memorize some songs, their titles, their artists, and one or two facts about them, but Haas blitzes out EXACTLY the details you need to know ahead of time. There were only a few things not on those, and if you go to even a few classes, you'll pick up on the added information.

comments.course: Very well-paced, not overly demanding. GREAT class.
comments.professor: Whelan's super passionate about the subject, and a great lecturer.
comments.workload: Yes, very manageable. Good readings too.

comments.course: The pacing for the course was great. Anyone who has taken BC Calc, this is definitely the right course. It wasn't terribly challenging, but it kept me on my toes.
comments.professor:
Van Erp is probably the best professor I've had at Dartmouth. He is a phenomenal lecturer, always making odd comments that keep it interesting, as well as being extremely easy to follow.

He's funny and easy to understand.
comments.workload: The workload was perfect for the course. The weekly problem sets were good for reinforcing material and were never a struggle to complete on time. There were a balance of challenging and easy problems, and the optional nightly homework really is optional: if you don't understand the material, do it.

comments.course: Prof Nichols is what makes this class worthwhile. She is great at lecturing and really willing to explain material in depth. The content is pretty interesting, but kind of dry at times, and the workload is not that bad. The tests are graded fairly, not hard but not easy
It is so tragic that Professor Crocker retired! He was great, this course was great, the work was a  bit hard.
What can I say, it's a Professor Moor class. The man is brilliant, the content is really engaging, and the workload is light and graded easily. What's not to like?
Great course, amazing professor, and easy workload. Win-Win-Win.

Professor Duthu is one of the best professors you'll encounter at Dartmouth, and this is the "easiest" and least specialized class he teaches. Absolutely take it! The readings help on the exams, but aren't required. Be warned though, Duthu doesn't grade easily, but he does grade fair.
Good professor, interesting topic, and very light workload.

Course is very interesting but much harder than the popular impression says it is. Fesen is a nice guy, but he purposely designs tests and quizzes with questions to trip you up. Also, there's a quiz every Thursday morning, uggg.

Professor Heschel is probably one of the nicest and most accommodating professors you'll meet. She does a great job at lecturing, and the course topic is very interesting and informative. Plus, pretty much an easy A as long as you show up and pay attention.
Interesting course, bit of a disorganized professor. Don't expect to learn much from lectures, but you will if you go to office hours.
One of the best courses I've taken at D with one of the best professors. If you plan on going to law school TAKE THIS CLASS.

I'll start off by saying that I'm not going to be a humanities major, to give you some context. This course really dragged out. The reading (Walden Pond, Borderlands La Frontera, others...) was not interesting for me. The best part of the course was the final paper about semiotics. I wished semiotics had been a more significant part, if not the focus of, the class.
comments.professor: Not a great professor. He seems bored with everything he does, he's a rather tough grader, and he doesn't help your writing at all. I received no feedback on my final paper (the only research paper, so it would have been nice to know how to improve, or if I even did well). He didn't help me improve my writing in any way.
comments.workload: The workload wasn't bad. There weren't too many essays, but don't put them off. The reading was spaced out fairly well too. The only issue was the final paper (which I've already said was the best part of the class). There was very little time to do enough research (1 week, I could've used 2) and then write a 10 page paper about it, but if you don't mind spending 3-4 evening of your reading period to do a good job, go for it.

comments.course: The course doesn't delve too deep into any particular topic within discrete math, so you get a chance to look at a bunch of different topics in the field.
comments.professor: Jayanti is great -- go to his office hours and come to class and you'll learn the material.
comments.workload: If you do the homeworks before the night before they are due, the assignments are all manageable.

comments.course: This course was great. I had taken AP Phys C in high school, so a lot of it was review. If that's your concern, read somebody else's review. The demos were pretty good, and the material is well presented, at least if you have LaBelle. Not my top rated class, but one of the best.
comments.professor: Professor LaBelle is a great lecturer. He has this quirky habit with thought questions that make you feel like you're 12 years old, but then you realize that they're actually tough questions, and that he's just being energetic. He did a great job presenting the material and was available during many office hours to help out if needed.
comments.workload: The workload was pretty consistent. The online problem sets weren't bad, although I highly recommend the help sessions at Thayer--show up as a group and power through the problem sets. There were definitely some very challenging problems, but if you somewhat enjoy physics, this won't bother you.

comments.course: The reading material for this course was excellent. I really enjoyed the books. However, the pace was irritatingly persistent. We had a read a new book each week (sounds manageable) but we also had to write a short essay once a week. It sounds not too bad, but for me it felt a little oppressive at times.
comments.professor: Aden was a great professor. He's interesting and knows how to really push your writing. He doesn't always know what to do to keep a discussion going, or how to explain his concept of a thesis--which is normal, just difficult.
comments.workload: I felt that the workload was pretty tough. There was a whole lot of writing, but if you can find a Seminar with minimal workload/writing, you're probably in the class everyone else wanted. If you like science fiction literature, take Literature of the Machine, but expect to do a lot of tough writing--6 two page essays and 2 longer ones--but at least it'll improve your writing abilities.

comments.course: The course was great. I had no programming experience coming in, and I never felt like I had no idea what was going on, but I definitely learned a lot. Even if programming started out as some scary monster for you, the course starts out slowly enough to explain it and then you can really do a lot with what you know. If anything, it was almost too slow.
comments.professor: Professor Taylor was nothing special. Some people in the class thought she was basically a "professional powerpoint reader", which was sometimes true. She wasn't a particularly engaging lecturer, but she was easy to follow and straightforward on material, giving excellent example programs. I've heard a lot of good things about Shepherd, so I was bummed not to be taking from him.
comments.workload: The workload was no problem. I had thought that the daily Short Assignments were going to be irritating, but they turned out not only to be extremely helpful for learning the material, but also even a little fun, tinkering with the program until it worked. The Long Assignments can be a little more challenging to get done, but I've heard they were easier this year than in previous years.

comments.course: This class is a horrible compromise. The first half was all about neuro, which the CS half of the students didn't care about, and I'm sure was so basic it was silly for the neuro people. The second half was some basic computer science, which didn't incorporate the bio at all—and the presence of non-CS people in the class meant it was incredibly hand-wavy. Overall a waste of time.
comments.professor: Granger just cares about being quippy and making jokes. It got pretty obnoxious.

comments.course: Really good course. Slightly more straightforward than P15 in that it was mostly just standard E&M, but still very difficult. Lectures consisted of Marcelo working through derivations and sample problems. Problem sets came from the textbook, which was phenomenal. I've never had a textbook that was more helpful and well written. Great tool to study from. Subject matter is interesting; applications in engineering and higher level physics are made clear. E&M is conceptually less intuitive than mechanics, but not much harder once you learn the fundamental laws.
comments.professor: Marcelo is AWESOME!! Definitely the best prof I had my freshmen year. He has a passion for his subject area that is unmatched, and loves teaching at every level. His lectures are clear as can be, and the best part was all of his tangents. We once spent 20 minutes as a class(which was only 7 people) discussing string theory and why he gave up on it. He talked about his research often, which was really interesting, because he is definitely a leader in theoretical physics. All in all, I never thought somebody could make me want to be a physics major so much! Even if it's physics 1/2, everyone should take a class with Marcelo.

comments.course: Great, great course if you love physics. I was unsure about taking P15 since I only took Physics B in high school and basically just needed physics for the engineering prereqs, but i'm so glad i took the honors course. The problem sets were very engaging, especially once we got into the material that no one had ever seen before on relativity and quantum mechanics. They were of course very difficult, but the TA was great at helping you get started on any problem.  Lectures could be a bit dry at times, but that was mostly during the beginning of the course, at which point we were basically reviewing classical mechanics. Now again, it is a harder class than P13, and should only be taken if you took Physics C in high school or you are a calculus and physics ace. But totally worth the work if you can do it.
comments.professor: Barrett was not the best prof I've had, but as you will realize, teaching physics can be done one way: by doing it. Lectures would consist of Barrett working through derivations and applications, which would frequently be mimicked on homeworks. He was much better at inspiring interest when we got to more advanced material on quantum mechanics. I can't say that I didn't fall asleep at times when he was in the middle of some lengthy derivations.

comments.course: Not a terribly interesting course, but the material is very logically paced. Prepare to review a bit of Math 11 and learn some linear algebra (if you didn't take 22) but it was nothing extraordinarily difficult. If you're interested in Diff Eq, then this course should be fine. If you need to take it for ENGS or something, also fine. Otherwise, probably not that great.
comments.professor: Professor Gordon gets distracted a lot in lectures and is kind of a bumbling old lady, but she got the material across pretty logically. You can tell she finds it really interesting, although she's a little boring to sit and listen to. Nothing special, but there's no reason she should stop you.
comments.workload: Daily problem sets are a bit much, but also helpful. Sometimes you have to spend 10-15 minutes figuring out exactly how the day's material applies to the homework, but it was nothing terrible to deal with.

comments.course: Every day for homework we'd have a small assignment (mostly just something to think about). Then in class Winkler would roll the die to figure out who would present on the homework. So the course was basically zero work, but the questions he posed (while easy) were fun to think about.
Course was basic intro to economics. Prof Curtis talk what was in the textbook, it was easy to follow if you get economics, and well-paced.
comments.professor: Curtis was very fair and accessible outside of class.
comments.workload: Workload was manageable. Two midterms, 5 or 6 problem sets and a final. Midterms were fair, medians usually around 85.

comments.course: The course was very interesting and useful. We learned about relevant things--monetary policy, inflation and so on. Fair amount of work though.
comments.professor: Rose is an engaging lecturer, she keeps you paying attention. She's helpful out of class, fair grader.
comments.workload: It was a pretty decent workload. Had to read a bunch of articles outside of class, two midterms, 6 problem sets and a final. Everything was graded fairly. Overall, decent amount of work but interesting and worth it.

comments.course: The course was actually pretty interesting. Learned some interesting stuff about hurricanes, waves, tides. Not going to blow you away, but somewhat interesting.
comments.professor: Osterberg is the best professor I've had at Dartmouth. So engaging, great guy, really wants everyone to do well. Take classes with him.
comments.workload: Easy workload. I think 6 homework assignments, a bunch of "quizzes" or midterms. I think 3 quizzes and 2 midterms and final. Then there was an optional paper that could boost your grader up to 10%. Very easily graded--if you put in a little bit of effort, you'll get an A.

comments.course: It was as interesting as Math can be. If you like math, it may be interesting. If not, you really don't learn anything of interest.
comments.professor: Barnett was a good prof. He was helpful outside of class and meant well. But again, he was teaching math so there wasn't a lot he could do.
comments.workload: There were homework assignments every week or two, two midterms and a final. Workload was very manageable, tests weren't too hard but easy to screw up. Only take this if you need to--it's not an easy class just because you were good at math in high school.

comments.course: Very interesting--learned about differing government styles in different countries like USSR, El Salvador, South Africa.
comments.professor: Horowitz is a great guy. Means well and wants his students to do well. Most classes were mostly lecture with some discussion, he's not the greatest lecturer but it's still easy to follow.
comments.workload: Two blue-book midterms, 5 page paper, and blue-book final. Readings every night which took some time but weren't bad. Horowitz graded fairly easily and definitely fairly.

comments.course: Pretty bland material. It covers everything in Micro, but it is certainly not exciting.
comments.professor: He was a pretty boring lecturer. Just plain white slides and he talked the whole time. I think he may get better, but the material wasn't thrilling and he didn't help a lot.
comments.workload: Just two midterms, final, and problem sets graded for completion. Very mathy course, overall not bad but I think non-econ majors struggled a lot.

comments.course: Boring lecturer, generally poor at explaining concepts. Textbook example of uninspired tenured professor.

Incredibly boring and completely useless. I mean she spent the whole class talking about the wood used in snowboards. I had hopes that we would spend the class talking about more common sports and equipment but spent most talking about bikes or skis. Not even interesting stuff about those skis.
comments.professor: She was pretty terrible. She was boring, a little oblivious during tests. I think everyone in the class could have fallen asleep and she would have kept rambling.
comments.workload: It wasn't bad. Open note tests, some homework assignments. But it was so hard to get inspired for the material that it made them harder.

comments.course: 26 is the most interesting and useful class in economics and maybe at the school. You'll learn everything you need to know about stocks, bonds, mortgages, government treasuries, derivatives. You must take this if you want to work in finance.
comments.professor: Kreicher was very fair and knowledgeable. He's a former Wall Street guy, so he added his own insight and stories when needed. He's a pretty hilarious guy too--I'd take this class with him if you could.
comments.workload: Lots and lots of work. No way around it. Read a chapter in a textbook before every class and answer questions. He calls on people in class to answer the questions, just like Kohn, so you have to be ready. It's 20% of your grade. Intense workload, one midterm and one final. If you put in the work, you can get an A and it's incredibly rewarding.

comments.course: The course was slow, somewhat interesting. We talked about the typical EARS intro course stuff, and some about global warming.
comments.professor: Hawley was fair and a great guy. I think he was overwhelmed by having like 300 people in the class but will probably be a lot better with a smaller class.
comments.workload: Very manageable. Some homework assignments, a term project that was easy, two or three midterms and a final. Lots of multiple choice but the median was low so it's curved. Easy A if you put in a little work.

comments.course: Very interesting and organized. You learn all of the introductory psych stuff, some of which you'll already know, but a lot that is very new and interesting.
comments.professor: They were helpful but since there was 4 it was hard to really rely on them.
comments.workload: Yes. 3 midterms and a final. Just read the textbook and you'll be fine. I don't get why people say it's hard. Just read the book, go to class and you'll get a high grade.

comments.course: Very interesting. Like 26 with a lot more math. Calculating present value and stock value and options. Again, very interesting and highly relevant for anyone looking towards finance.
comments.professor: Venti was very fair and a great guy. Not the most commanding lecturer, especially for a 2A, but the material was interesting enough to keep you paying attention. I'd take this class with him if possible.
comments.workload: Just two midterms and a final. No other grade booster. Had to prepare outside of class by reading the textbook and such. But not a whole lot of work, just had to work to understand the material.

comments.course: Just like any other EARS course. Interesting enough, but not going to blow you away.
comments.professor: Osterberg may be the best professor at Dartmouth. Just the man. Keeps you paying attention, wants you to do well, just asks for a little work and he'll reward you.
comments.workload: Very light. Some homeworks, class attendance then midterms/quizzes and final. Again, a little work will get you an A.

comments.course: Learned a lot about taxes, welfare, Medicare and other government programs. Highly relevant and interesting.
comments.professor: Skinner is a great prof. He really really cares about his students and will do anything to help.
comments.workload: Two quizzes, Midterm, Final, and 3 page policy memo. Additional outside readings, but very manageable and interesting. Take it.

comments.course: Not interesting really at all. You learn about why people buy houses where they do, and it is usually because of schools and the absence of dumps. I mean the whole class could be taught in like an hour but the same concepts just get dragged out.
comments.professor: Fischel is a nice guy, but a pretty lousy lecturer and doesn't use Blackboard. Certainly not inspirational.
comments.workload: There's really no work. Two non-cumulative midterms, a 4 page paper and an 8 page paper. No final. So there's no work, and I imagine it's easy to get a B+, but there's really no reason to take this class.

comments.course: Fast pace, interesting, and pretty straight-forward
comments.professor: Professor X was great. The TA's were some of the more awful people I have had the privilege of meeting in my Dartmouth career. They were incredibly condescending and I don't think they understood that people take this course to fill distributive requirements with minimum pain. Furthermore, they were rude...where does Dartmouth find these people?
comments.workload: Very consistent. Problem sets/tests every couple weeks. Do the readings and pay attention in class and you should have no problem getting an A in the class.

comments.course: Pretty interesting, but its title is a bit misleading. It's essentially entirely about face processing, so by the end of the term it can get a bit boring, as not many other aspects of social perception are discussed.
comments.professor: Duchaine is the man, funny, great lecturer, very friendly, all-around awesome guy. Some of the questions on his test were kind of annoying though, picking out little details from article.
comments.workload: A weekly little brief to make sure you do the readings, a midterm, a final, a paper, and a group presentation. None of them are too bad.

comments.course: One of the best profs that I've had at Dartmouth, she is great. Very helpful both in and out of class, really wants you to do well!
Mostly reasonable pace. Got a bit heavy at times.
comments.professor: Campbell's a great guy, but his lectures aren't very helpful and he often misunderstands questions.
comments.workload: Good amount of work, but hey, I learned android.

comments.course: nothing but positive things to say. cool material
comments.professor: balkcom is the man. great lectures. very clear.
comments.workload: reasonable, well-focused, interesting homeworks. well done.

comments.course: Very interesting, starts off a bit slow as the anatomical evolution of adaptations for bipedalism isn't the most interesting thing in the world, but then just gets more and more fascinating and fun. Lots of really cool videos are shown in class.
comments.professor: Dominy is awesome, great guy, pretty funny, clear lecturer, extremely knowledgable about tons of things. He's a fantastic professor and has done a ton of cool stuff, you should really go to office hours and just chill with him.
comments.workload: Readings weren't too bad and were pretty interesting, the only things that count to your grade are two midterms and a take-home final. Midterms weren't too bad, there were a few questions that were annoyingly just completely unimportant little factoids

comments.course: Interesting, well-paced, and probably semi-applicable to the real business world. Case studies were pretty frequent and always very interesting and informative.
comments.professor: Professor Peteraf is great, she's very nice, a very clear lecturer, and she tries to make class pretty entertaining.
comments.workload: Only four one-page homework assignments (and you get to drop one) and three midterms (no final). The midterms are pretty straight forward and easy, plus you can bring in a page of notes so you don't even really need to study that much.

comments.course: this course was really hard. imo only people genuinely interested in econ should do it.
comments.professor: his lecturing is really dry and boring, but his slides are amazing. very detailed.

comments.course: too many books to read. it affected my work on other courses
professor heatherton is great!
comments.professor: the workload was good.

comments.course: This was quite possibly the worst class I've taken at Dartmouth. My only regret it not dropping it sooner. The lab, lecture, and reading had nothing to do with one another and when it came to the test it was almost guess work. Office hours were almost mandatory in order to understand what was going on in the class.
comments.professor: Lipson was cool and helpful. She did lots of demos but when it came time for the test she expected us to know everything...literally EVERYTHING! Even the stuff she said wouldn't be on the tests.
comments.workload: It was a lot of work with lab, class readings and assignments but it's not all that surprising.

comments.course: Great class. It was all about writing memoirs so basically just writing stories about your life. If you are into creative writing at all I would suggest this class.
comments.professor: The prof is actually sort of famous. He has writing a lot of promenant religion papers and books. The course doesn't focus on religion but the readings come back to it now and then. He was easy to talk to, understanding and interesting. Best of all when you went to his office he would sit and read through your paper line by line and help you choose words, syntax, or whatever you needed to make a good piece of writing. Prof also knows many of the authors that wrote the books for class so you get to sometimes meet them depending on the school year and skype etc.
comments.workload: The readings seem sort of intimidating (1 book per week) but its not at all that bad. They are all interesting and helpful books (more memoirs). The best thing about the writing was that you could do it over and over until you had something good and also if you were running late it was possible for an extension.

comments.course: Just an average French 1 class. Nothing too interesting. Sort of hard the first few weeks when you don't understand anything and drill can suck but its a good class. Learned a lot.
comments.professor: A really funny prof. He loves having students visit him in his office because he is bored and just likes to talk. He is basically just a character from Ratatouille that came to teach French at Dartmouth. Murphy is also a lax grader but doesn't usually teach French 1.
comments.workload: Just normal work. I know this prof gave less work than the others so it was easier but also it was harder going into French 2 with a weak writing base.

comments.course: Best class I have taken so far. Really interesting, and made a lot of sense. Dominy jumps around with his interests but stays chronological so its easy to stay focused. The first test can be intimidating but after you figure out what he wants it is a lot easier.
comments.professor: Amazing Prof. I loved the class with him and am now taking another class with him. Sort of nerdy, awkward guy but incredibly nice and intelligent. He knows his stuff and really loves his job. Go to his office at least once just to get to know him and see the cool stuff he has there (Piltdown Man skull replica, stuffed bonobo, shark calling floats etc). He is also a freshman advisor and loves helping out freshman. Great guy and great prof.
comments.workload: Super easy. There was reading every week but its almost optional based on how the prof lectures. If you don't understand something it is a good back up. No other work besides that.

comments.course: This course was meh. Not crazy interesting. Perez made the class feel like it was a large lecture and didn't seem to want to have fun on the topics that we were doing. There was a lot of potential with studying Voodoo, Rastafarianism and other really interesting religions but this class basically glossed over them. I was expecting more and could see this class being great if it was slowed down and enjoyed by the prof.
comments.professor: Helpful and fair. The papers in the class weren't hard at all, some just took more time. If you want help just biltz the prof and she's good about meeting and talking with students.
comments.workload: Lots of reading. Usually you could skim and the next day in class when we went over it you would be fine. A lot of the discussion was based on opinion. If you didn't want to participate in class that would be your loss but the prof doesn't take off much of the grade.

comments.course: Good class about children's stories. A very interesting Writing 5 and very helpful to my writing. You get unlimited rewrites and the prof wants you to do well so she doesn't mind reading over the paper multiple times.
comments.professor: Prof was sort of awkward and strange but she was nice and helpful. She knew her stuff and has worked in publishing and children's books for years. She encourages you to talk with the authors and figure out if they knew what they were writing and how it came to them.
comments.workload: Lots of reading and rewrites but that is what is needed to make a better writer. She loved to workshop and present so it didn't seem like hard work just sometimes it got boring. Looking back most of it was helpful in how to write a paper and I appreciated the fact that she could help everyone no matter what their skill level was in writing.

comments.course: I would recommend it.  Lectures are mostly fascinating, but it's non-stop information from start to stop.
comments.professor: Udi knows his stuff in and out and is a great guy. Answers emails quickly,  is helpful in office hours.
comments.workload: Workload good. Sometimes the readings seemed to be too much, but they were usually fairly interesting. Never really seemed like busy work, anything he assigned us we would discuss and understand the importance of.

comments.course: Pretty easy distrib, sometimes class isn't that interesting but Osterberg is a great prof and absolutely loves what he teaches! There are 6 homeworks, 4 quizzes and 3 tests. Osterberg sometimes pulls from the reading but if you skim, you'll get it

I love Rose! This was an amazing class. There are 4 problem sets, 2 midterms and a final. There are also a couple of blog post/discussions that are easy to do. Rose does a great job explaining concepts and applying everything you've learned to current economic situations. Highly recommend
disorganized, but easy going and super chill

I love Bronski, he does a great job of leading discussions! We had a 1 pg response paper due every week, a 7 page paper and then a 15 pg final paper. For homework we had reading you could skim and movies to watch. Great class!
Fantastic class for people interested in the philosophy behind government.
comments.professor: Best professor I've had at Dartmouth. He's the reason I want to major in gov.
comments.workload: Lots of reading.

comments.course: Very interesting course, fascinating material, useful for real life.
comments.professor: Great profs. Heck is an amazing lecturer and Hockley knows tons about the subject. Somewhat difficult grading but relatively fair I think.
comments.workload: Readings seem optional. A bit of memorization for the final and midterm but otherwise not too bad. Just lots of info.

comments.course: Interesting course, interesting discussions. Would be a really good seminar but was a HORRIBLE writing 5 course. Didnt get ANY critique or help on my writing style (may have actually ended up worse off). Really was looking forward to writing improvement but didnt get that at all. Dont take it unless you think you're already a good writer! Some parts of our class discussions were pointless.
comments.professor: Nichols is a really nice person. He goes on rambling for a bit but is generally alright. Not my favorite prof but not my least favorite either.
comments.workload: Really easy. Just essays. Some reading. Not bad.

comments.course: I took this course to get a sci distrib, and ended up liking it so much! Dobson is great and knows how to keep his classes interesting for everyone, no matter what your science/anthro background is like, so I highly recommend taking any of his courses!
comments.professor: His lectures are great, he's a funny guy so he keeps lectures entertaining

comments.course: She's so intelligent, but when it comes to her students she really isn't all that helpful and can even come off as mean sometimes
comments.professor: WAYYYYY too much reading

comments.course: This course on curating microcinema was super interesting and fun! More of a project based class with no exams and just a few short response papers (like 2 pages each), highly recommend any of Jodie's courses!
comments.professor: One of the most enthusiastic and energetic profs I've ever had, she's super young and a lot of fun!

comments.course: Such a sweet prof, grades super easy, and you just want her to be your grandmother by the end of the term haha
Her lectures are interesting, and she's definitely witty and sarcastic, but she will not budge on a due date so don't bother asking for an extension
Animation history, how could it not be a great class?
comments.professor: Perfect prof for the film department, Jodie brings excitement and a fun attitude to class everyday and makes the course more fun than you expect!

comments.course: An entire course on musicals, so much fun if you're into them!
don't take intro art history courses unless you absolutely have to, they are the worstttt
I was just really uninterested in byzantine and early christian art, so i didn't like this class at all
So much work
super structured, but a lot of work, usually mindless interpolation. there are only a few concepts though, and once you get those down everything is plug and play.

NOT an easy A class. Every x-hour is technically used, although we were occasionally released early if watching a movie (this means typically three hours spent in class on Mondays - usually movie-watching time, sometimes lecture). Interesting in that we did not focus on classic movies but rather movies of various genres that I probably wouldn't have found or thought to watch on my own.
comments.professor: Very difficult paper grader in the sense that what seems to be appreciated is direct repetition of the prompt and listing of the technical aspects of the film - centering papers around a theme or thesis outside of the film techniques not exactly appreciated...
comments.workload: Readings important for quizzes (at least for the first half of the term); several papers throughout the term (occasionally with scene/shot drawings that take quite a bit of time) and a final paper. Most difficult paper was one based off of "film-events" outside of class. These films were shown at the Hop/Loew with the director present, and it typically wasn't possible to view them more than once.

comments.course: How well you do in the course depends entirely on how much Heckman likes you. I practically bombed both quizzes and still got an A because I participated and put up with his shit.
comments.professor: Carey Heckman...where to start? He's the most opinionated man I've ever met, and he also finds a way to become pretty creepy. It's kind of scary how much the man learns about all of his students, which would be a good thing, but he's constantly trying to relate and make jokes. If you're a future philosophy major, watch out! Also, I think he read our facebooks. Make that shit private.
comments.workload:
As far as a freshman seminar goes, there was a lot of reading, and it was all very technical and pretty difficult to understand. It all got discussed in class, but it was still a struggle.

The first two papers required you to define computer science and determine its purpose from the readings Heckman gave you, which wasn't too bad. He takes the imperative to teach you to write very seriously, which could be good, but didn't seem too necessary with our class. The third paper is a research paper on an aspect of computer science, which was a lot more work for a freshman seminar.

comments.course: Don't take it unless you're a ling major. It was very interesting, it was an easy A, and I learned a lot, but I didn't get any distribs for it, and the final paper was hell.
comments.professor: Ernst is a very funny guy, and extremely enthusiastic about what he does. He really made the course fun
comments.workload: Throughout the term, the only work was to do exercises in the textbook and to look up the etymology of words, which was fine. The first two essays were just busywork (rephrase the information in these chapters of these books), but the research paper required serious amounts of effort that I hadn't had to put into the class up to that point.

comments.course:
really disorganized proff, but at least the work load is light.
the project was really unfair, some groups got a super easy version of the problem, and others got a massive one.
Interesting, somewhat confusing if you're not an ears major - but most info is pretty straight forward - don't need to analyze material, you just need to know it
comments.professor: Entertaining, didn't handle the huge class (200+) exceptionally well but did a good job at covering material and answering questions
comments.workload: Quizes on readings (but labeled on syllabus which days/readings) midterm had some trick questions but very direct, straight off class notes/lectures, very little reading assigned for the class

comments.course: Easy, straight forward lectures but somewhat detached from actual assignments
comments.professor: Fowler is a very big name in her field - very knowledgeable
comments.workload: 3 papers, discussion group - readings not entirely necessary

comments.course: Very interesting material, unannounced quizzes, short paper and long paper
comments.professor: Green is one of the best professor's on this campus
comments.workload: Manageable, have to keep up on readings to pass the quizzes (which are easy if you even just skim the readings) paper's were fun and easy to get in to

comments.course: Lab was fun, in class was dull - took as a none science for my lab and the midterm/final crushed me - very specific details when I was expecting more big picture
comments.professor: Magilligan is great - super dorky but really great, very smart and willing to help, tries to keep it as entertaining as possible
comments.workload: Lab's took the most time, final project was fun not a lot of reading

comments.course: I was so in over my head - took as a pre-req for my minor - no phil background
Fun material, went through the history and place of religion in the US - from mainstream to the fringy stuff
comments.professor: Balmer is a really great prof, great lecturer, really fun and entertaining- highly recommend
comments.workload: 100% lecture based - only 2 tests which worked against some people - but the ID's and short answers were straight off the lectures

comments.course: REALLY AWESOME - class was in Rauner library and every class prof Kenseth would pull books from the collections based on a theme (atlases, religious, new world discover, collections etc) and we'd discuss their impacts and the evolution of the book and print.
comments.professor: Kenseth is amazing, very smart and very amiable, very helpful with final projected
comments.workload: no necessary readings, midterm, a few short write ups and a final project that was easy but time consuming

comments.course: Not with GLICK - with Prof Huber (visiting prof) he was absolutely awesome
best proff ever
Ethics, Law and Everyday Life - not my favorite Muirhead course, but very good class
comments.professor: THE BEST lecturer at Dartmouth, hands down.

comments.course: Very interesting - look at Jerusalem and Athens and their political thought and then how they merge in modern times
comments.professor: Murphy is a little awkward and goofy but he's brilliant and has so much knowledge it's insane. Great facilitator of discussions
comments.workload: 2 essays, lead a class discussion, need to at least skim the reading to be able to contribute to discussion - very intimate class where you get to know your classmates, it was one of my favorite classes at Dartmouth

comments.course: Crushed me - I hate language
comments.professor: Very good prof, very helpful and sympathetic to those who struggle with language

comments.course: LOVE THIS CLASS - political history of the US - inspired me to be a gov major - Locke to Lincoln, with the Federalists, writings on slavery, writing the constitution etc
comments.professor: Hands down the best lecturer at Dartmouth - truly amazing and inspiring
comments.workload: 2 essays and a final - relevant to course work

comments.course: Really interesting class - HARD tests, only 3 short (15 questions) multiple choice tests that were trickier than expected
comments.professor: Really really great prof - but might suggest looking at other classes of his to take

comments.course: AMAZING.
comments.professor: Typical writing 5 - essays, rewrite essays, more essays, responses, google docs and wikis

comments.course: Igoe assigns a lot of readings, but you learn quickly that you don't have to do them all. He gives a very detailed study guide before each test that literally has all of the questions that can possibly be on the test on it. If you put in the time and get that study guide done, you can do great even if you don't do all of the course work throughout the term.
Psyc 1 is a necessary evil, but for an introductory course it's not too bad.
comments.professor: I personally liked Bucci's style of going by the book and delivering clear lectures. Wheatley also gave great lectures. Kelley is all over the place, but keeps class interesting. Kleck is good as well, but just not as engaging as the others in my opinion.
comments.workload: Read the book and use the study guide.

comments.course: The course attempted in vain to explore an interesting question. It concerns a very specific subfield, which only has 4 or so authors publishing in it, one of whom happens to be the instructor.
comments.professor: Accessible and well meaning, however she is very dogmatic in her opinions.

comments.course: The course was not bad for a statistics course.
comments.professor: Professor Pfister goes out of his way to make sure that students understand the material, although he does have a tendency to go on tangents that add absolutely nothing to the learning experience.
comments.workload: The workload is not terrible, but there's also no way to BS the course. You have to do the work and do it correctly.

comments.course: The course itself is very useful for anyone who intends to perform social science research.
comments.professor: Professor Duchaine only taught about the first third of the course. The quality of the TA really depends on which one is assigned to your group.
comments.workload: The workload was on the light side, although the final project can take quite a bit of time.

comments.course: PSYC 25 is a very standard developmental psychology course.
comments.professor: Professor Scheiner keeps class entertaining, but uses a lot of the class time to talk about her family or tell other stories. She brings the material to life, however, and does it with a sense of humor.
comments.workload: Don't even bother reading the book. Many people didn't even go to class.

comments.course: This is a wonderful course for anyone interested in education issues.
comments.professor: Professor Harris was great. His experience as a superintendent greatly added to the course.
comments.workload: The workload was very manageable.

comments.course: Favorite course at Dartmouth. The material is so interesting and the professor is awesome!
comments.professor: Professor Tine is great - if you're interested in education at all, be sure to take a course with her!
comments.workload: The workload is average.

comments.course: The course was interesting, but a bit dry at times.
comments.professor: I didn't particularly care for Professor Ball's teaching style, but it wasn't terrible.
comments.workload: Not much work at all.

comments.course: Very manageable for a religion course - it's structured as a history course.
comments.professor: Prof. Balmer was funny and interesting, to the extent that you can be in a religion course.
comments.workload: Very easy course with regards to workload. Memorize the material and you're set.

comments.course: The course was a discussion-based class. It was okay, but not spectacular.
comments.professor: Professor Kay really cares about his students. Great prof.
comments.workload: Light workload. Two lectures, a few papers, and a short final.

comments.course: Well-organized and relevant course.
comments.professor: Very clear and engaging teaching style
comments.workload: The workload doesn't seem to be heavy on the syllabus, but the two papers take a lot longer than they look. The tests are moderately difficult, but fair.

comments.course: The class was organized and related to students' lives.
comments.professor: Professor Hull is very blunt, but funny and relatable.
comments.workload: Read the book and go to class and you will do fine.

comments.course: Was a little unprepared. We'd occasionally get side-tracked in class because we'd find an issue with one of his proofs that we'd then work through collectively. It was a nice exercise (one time we found a flaw in the original paper!) but often put us behind schedule.
The course was interesting only when the professor tried too hard to make it interesting.
comments.professor: Kelley is funny at times, but he sacrifices clarity and detail to do so.
comments.workload: Don't buy the book. Go to class and memorize the slides and you will do well.

comments.course: The material is very interesting, but the sources that the professor uses have an obvious conservative bias.
comments.professor: Professor Elliott is very knowledgeable, but unfortunately chooses to focus on one perspective of the available research exclusively.
comments.workload: The workload was fairly significant - we wrote 3 papers over 12 pages and gave 2 lectures (50+ minutes long). He also gives packets of blog posts and research abstracts for students to read - but you really don't have to look at them until you write the papers.

comments.course: Not great but better than econ 10 and at least you don't have to send out annoying surveys like Gov 10
comments.professor: Im sure professor Hull is a great prof, but teaching statistics is pretty inherently boring.

comments.course: This was Mormonism with Balmer. It was incredible interesting and not too difficult.
comments.professor: One of the best lecturers I've had. Really loved our projects.
comments.workload: A mindterm, a final and a paper/presentatin thats about 5 pages. Not too bad and usually little work between classes. Perfect sophomore summer 2A.

comments.course: Very mathy course, seemed very task-level most of the time, simply memorizing equations and plugging numbers in.
A bit awkward, but loves his work and is interesting.
Took it for a CI, not worth it.
comments.professor: One of the most biased profs I've had at Dartmouth. Her opinions were the only ones that mattered.

comments.course: Best prof ever. lots of itneresting facts about math!
Best class. Cant say enough, lots of work. Its difficulty is overhyped.

This wasn't a particularly interesting class. I actually put a lot of work into it and did the readings, so I thought it could have been interesting but it was ruined by all the kids who didnt come to class or came and did nothing (but still got As)
This course was great. Hawley is great. It was easy because of the extra credit offered but other than that it wasn't particularly easy.
comments.professor: Workload was not bad. We usually had one problem set every couple of weeks.

comments.course: Prof. Curtis was great. She really wants to work with you and made it much easier freshman fall.

I took this class freshman fall without realizing that it was largely thought to be an athlete easy course. It was really interesting to me, I actually went to office hours so he guided me in my writing in the papers.
Best course so far. Lots of guest speakers. Information you cannot get anywhere else!
comments.professor: Lots of work, but it's fun.

comments.course: Great material, interesting
comments.professor: Convoluted lectures.  Very motivated, but unfortunately, she lacks the teaching experience necessary .

comments.course: Class was pretty interesting and well-paced, although it took a little while for me to get into it personally, as I am not really a huge fan of poetry at heart.
comments.professor: McCann is a fantastic lecturer and really knows a lot about Romantic literature. He is also good in office hours although he can use a lot of complicated jargon at times. He isn't a harsh grader though and is very willing to help you with your papers. He definitely appreciates it when students come see him beforehand about papers.
comments.workload: This class is definitely a manageable workload. You'll mostly be reading poems, so the reading isn't too long, (aside from Frankenstein and Caleb Williams). Since McCann is such a good lecturer it is definitely possible not to do all of the reading and still get a lot out of the class, and there are only 3 papers (2 short and 1 long) so not too onerous.

comments.course: Absolutely amazing prof.  Created the syllabus on his own, had it completely memorized, presented it in a Socratic manner, moved at a perfect pace, was super congenial and helpful outside of class, and was generally completely awesome.

Really interesting course! Learned a lot!

A BIG TIP FOR ALL WHO WANT TO TAKE THIS CLASS-- you will have a much easier time if you pick a preexistent dataset (i.e. contact the author of a paper to see if you can use their dataset) instead of picking a topic and finding the data for it.
comments.professor: Edmonds is an incredible professor. Be prepared for some friendly condescension... in the best way possible. Honestly, he just wants you to prepare you to write a substantial paper.
comments.workload: This class is undoubtedly a lot of work. Edmonds gives pretty solid deadlines/grades. Even if you screw up a few times (I sure did!), it's still possible to get an A!

comments.course: Super interesting! Better when you have more people speak up in class. Bumpus reconciles this by having small group discussions throughout the class.
comments.professor: Bumpus is hands down one of the nicest/best professors at Dartmouth!
comments.workload: Definitely a manageable class! If you have a hard class lined up, this is a great complement because it's so interesting, and she is a very fair grader.

comments.course:
Solid course, but definitely NRO it! It's nice to have the option of taking the NR if all of your other classes are out of control during finals.

Learned a lot about basic accounting.
comments.professor: Really nice guy. Super understanding. He does a nice job with material which can be super dry.
comments.workload: Definitely manageable. You can mess up the homeworks and still get full credit as long as you showed some effort.

comments.course: Really interesting survey course of development economics!
comments.professor: Great prof! Really helpful in office hours. Made all of the difference.
comments.workload: Totally manageable/fair.

comments.course: As my first engineering course, I thought this class was extremely helpful in introducing me to how different systems function. This professor established important concepts in the beginning and continued to apply these same principles throughout each section. Repetitive, but necessary. The labs were sometimes unproductive because your results were often predicated on luck. If you didn't get good enough results, then you had to redo the lab.
comments.professor: The professor distributed his hand written notes to the class before the lecture. He then went over them on the overhead projector. His notes are pretty good but you will need to go beyond them and try some more examples for yourself so you can better prepare for the quizzes. The textbook was essentially useless.
comments.workload: The work load was heavy, especially for sophomore summer, but if you knew your stuff, the homework wasn't impossible to complete on your own. The MATLAB stuff could present occasional hurdles, but there were TA's to help.

comments.course: Not that interesting. Good third class if you have a hard term.
comments.professor: Kind of difficult/disorganized sometimes. A little too aware of the fact that it's a football team layup class.
comments.workload: Sometimes I spent way too much time on those labs. That being said, it usually worked out, so it was probably worth it. A little difficult at first for those who have no programming experience... otherwise, it's a layup.

comments.course: The course would be interesting normally, but Johnson goes out of his way to make it terrible.
comments.professor: HUGE jerk.
comments.workload: Workload was alright.

comments.course: It was great. Leearned a ton about actual OS and got to hack Linux and Solaris internals. Final project was patching the Linux kernel. The patch ended up being 6000+ lines. Great learning experience.
comments.professor: Sergey is an awesome prof, a little mismanaged sometimes but you learn a ton and build a great relationship.
comments.workload: Workload tends to be easy except for the midterm and the final project which are very hands on and technical and take a few all-nighters. If you can manage your time well you will be in great shape. I had to crunch through a lot of stuff for the final project which was mostly my fault for starting a two month project a few days before the deadline

comments.course: Nice course, but moves way too slowly. Now that the major doesn't require *everyone* to take this class, I wonder if the pace will speed up.
comments.professor: Explains things very clearly—nearly to the point of beating a dead horse. When the class is full of systems kids that need to take it for their major, though, I guess this is appreciated.

comments.course: Well-paced and interesting, the material is cutting edge and could be quite useful.
comments.professor: Phan is incredibly smart and quite helpful.  He is not the most engaging lecturer, but he has some incredible anecdotes.
comments.workload: Lighter workload compared to other engs courses, but I feel like I have still learned a lot.

comments.course: Dolph is a little socially awkward but is sarcastic-funny and sets reasonable expectations
Sutton is well intentioned but not helpful.  Smart guy, but does't carry over to class.

People will tell you "avoid this class." You will be a national merit semifinaling, 4.0ing, two sport varsity captaining, freshman.  You will say "naw, I'm up for a challenge."  This class is not about a challenge. It feels random, nothing ever gets graded, and the professor, while she has good intentions, does not care about you.
While the focus of "in the news" isn't covered much, this is to your benefit as it introduces you to most introductory material in the bio curriculum (unlike all the other Bio 11s)
comments.professor: McClung is brilliant, McPeek is world famous.  Take this course.
comments.workload: A fair amount of work

comments.course: Exactly what you'd expect out of an intro microecon class.  Won't be taking more econ classes but not because of this class.
comments.professor: Problem sets are graded on a check, check plus, check minus scale.  One is thrown out

comments.course: Madigan was a nice guy and made the class incredibly easy.  Take it with him if he teaches it again
comments.professor: 3 problem sets, got extra credit on two of them.  One EC essay.

comments.course: I liked the class overall; it was a good overview of a very broad topic. We got to read bits and pieces of various Russian authors, and our textbook went over all of Russian history--not a huge amount of detail, but good for getting a sense of who the Russians are and why their culture is the way it is.
comments.professor: Gronas is a little scatter-brained, but I think we got a good sense of Russian culture through his teaching style.  He is brilliant, but sometimes hard to follow.
comments.workload: Workload was fine; some of the projects seemed a less than relevant to Russian culture (we had to create an "-ism" and have a piece of visual art, music, literature, etc. for our movement.)

comments.course: It was a good course--a variety of stories and readings that were pretty interesting, fun projects and discussions
comments.professor: Rakova is THE BEST PROFESSOR EVER. If you ever have a chance to take a class with her, do it. It will probably be one of your top 5 best life choices.
comments.workload: It was a lot of work, but all of it was valuable and worth doing.

comments.course: I recommend it.  It took me about until this class to really be able to have conversations about real things in Russian, so this class was neat because our class discussions got pretty lively.
comments.professor: Rakova is always pretty patient and encouraging, but she will also push you to do better if she thinks you can. I highly recommend taking any class Rakova is teaching.
comments.workload: The workload in Russ 28 was better than in 27 in terms of being able to stay on top of assignments.

comments.course: Smith's a bit of a crazy mess. Lectures are pretty scatterbrained, and the notes are online.
It was interesting, thought-provoking, and we learned a lot of Russian.
comments.professor: I have never had a professor better than Rakova. She could lecture about dust bunnies and make it fun. Her style of teaching, her way of relating to her students, how she motivates you to really do your best--she is just fantastic.
comments.workload: Not too much, not too little.

comments.course: Fascinating, fascinating course. Lectures were jam-packed with information, but they were highly organized so they were really easy to follow. If you take detailed notes you'll do really well on the tests. I would definitely recommend this course for anyone interested in Germany.
comments.professor: Greenberg is extremely knowledgeable about the material. He's super nice and helpful, so definitely go to office hours or email him if you have questions. He's not a pushover when it comes to grading, but he's not unfair either. He's very strict when it comes to the policies of the class, sometimes annoyingly so; just make sure you follow his paper guidelines (word count especially). Overall a great professor- I'd def take him again.
comments.workload: Workload was pretty manageable. During the week you read primary sources (usually a couple pages), and then for discussion on Fridays you have to read a secondary source (usually at least 100 pages), so I recommend you start reading the secondary source at the beginning of the week so you're not trying to read a dense book on Thursday night. There are wo papers, a midterm, and final. Pretty straightforward.

comments.course: Class was well-structured and tied together a lot of different aspects of previous Russian language classes.
comments.professor: Prof Rakova is the best ever.
comments.workload: Don't get behind on work because it builds up fast, but if you keep up then it's fine.

comments.course: It's pretty grammar-intensive, but a good class all the same.
comments.professor:
Garretson is nice sometimes, but she'll also have a couple people that she consistently picks on.  If she likes you it's fine, but if she doesn't it's tough.
She knows her stuff, but isn't necessarily the best teacher
comments.workload: Workload was decent, and steady throughout the term

comments.course: Moor doesn't teach the course, really. You teach yourself and your TA helps.

So, you want to be a doctor? First, take this weeder course so that you're entirely sure. You're going to have to compete with another hundred premeds, all trying to get the A. And the course is graded on a curve, so you definitely won't get the grade you want. What, you're interested in biology for any reason other than medicine? That's too bad, you'll still have to suffer through this course. But at least you'll learn some science, even though it won't really be relevant until you take specific foundation courses.
comments.professor: Peart is a good lecturer who gets across the material about evolutionary biology. Jack, on the other hand, is not effective. His material is less intuitive, and he's very dry. Expect to find yourself dozing off on days he teaches, just waking up to answer clicker questions.

comments.course: If you have to take it, take it with Maue. If you just want a foundation course, you should look somewhere else.
comments.professor: Velez is very funny and an engaging lecturer, but he has difficulty explaining the material to the class. Several times, he taught us the wrong thing one day, and the next day, had to go back and apologize and try to explain it again. His examples are very specific and not out of the textbook, and you will be expected to know them.
comments.workload: Make sure you read the text and go to class. You won't understand one without the other, and questions from both will be on the exams. Speaking of exams, all three (yes, three) midterms and the final are doozies. Velez drops the worst grade, but you'll still need to study your ass off to figure out his weird multiple choice questions

comments.course: Really interesting. There's two midterms and then a final paper. The simulation was actually pretty fun. You just have a lot of readings to do but the course is really interesting.
Lectures alternated between student presentations of papers (sometimes interesting) and campbell explaining exactly what we need to do to complete a lab (tiresome, unnecessary).
comments.professor: Campbell's a bit of a mess.
comments.workload: For the assignments, he'd give us a PDF containing a screenshot of 95% of the code we needed to write, and we'd spend several hours manually copying that code into Eclipse. Not super fun, and you didn't really have to know what you were doing. Average amount of work, as hours go.

comments.course: Really great for a lab distrib. The labs were often outside and were really interesting. Not that much work either.
Very easy but very interesting.
Not as interesting as I thought it would be.
Super interesting material but not the best prof and the labs really need to be updated
comments.professor: Final project takes A LOT of time, and is during finals period

comments.course: Boring, boring, boring
comments.professor: Tried hard to make the material interesting.  Screwed over a lot of people with grading

comments.course: Loved this class.  One of my favorites at Dartmouth
comments.professor: Really good at explaining the material.  Very helpful during the final project
comments.workload: Had to do reading and answer Bb questions before each class.  Problem sets and labs took a lot of time

comments.course: Not as interesting as I thought it would be.
Don't take it with Pauls.  Doesn't teach well.  Makes things more confusing
Very interesting, but very fast paced. It's hard to keep up a lot of the time, and the material doesn't stop for you. If you don't have a background in CS, get ready for a ride.
comments.professor: Cormen is the smartest dick you will ever meet here. He's incredibly arrogant, but still deserves to be so. Don't ever argue for points though, you won't get anything out of him. In fact, he prides himself in taking more points than he gives if you request a regrade. Stay on his good side though and you'll find yourself with a lot of research opportunities.
comments.workload: SO MUCH FUCKING WORK. I've taken some tough classes here and this beats them all in terms of workload. The labs take 10-12 hours to do, and there are frequent short assignments. Plus, the exams are actually pretty hard.

comments.course: Mostafa is a total boss.
What a brilliantly interesting course. Take it if you like thinking about math and puzzling over things more than you ever have before.
comments.professor: Rebecca Weber is awesome in every way. Exceedingly knowledgeable, helpful, and organized, she clearly knows how to run her class. She's also really funny and her office hours are super helpful. Take it with her.
comments.workload: This class was a metric fuckton of work. The problem sets varied between 3 hours in length to 20 hours in length. You will live in tutorial sessions. Some of the problems are literally impossible to figure out without a hint from your TA.

comments.course: Not very interesting. Beethoven was a horrible man in my opinion. His work is ehh and it's not like Haringer will make you any more in love with it, since he's more of a Music History guy. Don't be fooled by the no prereq designation-- you better know how to read a score. The reading was actually pretty interesting-- especially the articles, but sometimes we'd have two pieces to listen to and an article and a chapter out of a book, and it was just too much. Not an easy A with Haringer for sure.
comments.professor: Avoid Haringer like the plague. He's enthusiastic and knowledgable for sure. But he's inexperienced. Usually a hard-ass with quizzes. Didn't really convey a true love for the music. Gets disappointed when everyone gets a 14/15 on a quiz, because it was too "easy." Doesn't know how to lecture clearly. Lectures are in fact erratic and do not provide a clear framework, connection, etc. Not helpful during office hours.
comments.workload: Workload is a lot more than a typical music class. If you're looking for an easy MUS art distrib, take MUS 4 with Levin hands-down. MUS 4 will be a whole lot more memorable and it'll change your view of music a lot more than MUS 10.

comments.course: A lot of the reading is actually really dry-- you have to read excerpts from a coffee table book on opera-- which is not too bad, and a book with a bunch of firsthand documents, which can usually be hit or miss. This class though can change your life, especially as a musician, since basically all of classical music after the 1700s was influenced by operatic techniques, styles, etc. Opera in general is a pretty cool genre-- if you like plays, dance, fashion, theater, orchestral music, vocal music-- it's basically all that combined.
comments.professor: Haringer had office hours where he would review before each quiz which was basically a lifesaver. Not too much a fan of his lectures-- too disorganized and he moves really fast.
comments.workload: Workload was pretty overwhelming at times. Having to watch two acts from an opera and read 60 pages plus another 20 pages from the Somerset-Ward is actually not what I was expecting for a music class. Consider this a class on opera history with a little musical stuff thrown in here and there.

comments.course: Snyder tries to discuss every topic like it's profound. So what is YOUR example on a positive externality? What is YOUR example on a tragedy of the commons type problem? Cold-calling gets really annoying/intimidating also. He doesn't lecture almost at all.
comments.professor: Professor is smart but puts on a front by saying he worked on a textbook problem for an hour trying to use the chain rule or something. Sometimes it's hard to know whether he knows his sh*t. He doesn't have the best reputation of being good during office hours. He can be pretty humble though-- tries to respect students' opinions.
comments.workload:
Do the problem sets I guess. 
All the exam material is from problem sets or lecture notes.

comments.course: The subject matter is super interesting and the books assigned are amazing...
comments.professor: Professor is nice but sucks. Shitty accent, not an amazing grasp of French and really subpar class discussions
comments.workload: Not too hard

comments.course: Warning...this FSP is intense. It's great that you get off 3 weeks early, but there's little rest while the program is going
Mostafa is a total boss.
Try to take anything with Magilligan. I loved this course by him the most.
One of my favorite courses at Dartmouth
A lot of work, but well worth. Get a fantastic glimpse into the life of a Roman
To me, Fox is pretty boring of a prof.
My favorite course at Dartmouth. Too bad the professor retired.
Took it for first year fellows, which I didn't get. Not sure if it was worth it, but it was interesting enough.
Do not take unless you have to. Too much hassle
His lectures are pretty monotonous. Pretty easy to sleep in though.
Do not take a class with Gordon! She does not know what she is talking about.
AWESOME!

Ok course, gets better as term progresses. Class lectures are sometimes unorganized and it is hard to grasp what is actually important to understand. Also sucks that the class is so big. I would only recommend this class if you have an interest in public policy. If you do, you'll enjoy parts of the class. If you have no interest in public policy and are just taking it for the first year fellows, you probably won't enjoy it.
comments.professor: Good professor, but not the best lecturer. No power point slides, just talking most of the time.  Quite knowledgeable about the subject though and enjoyable to talk to outside of class.
comments.workload: Lot of reading, but you don't really need to do all of it. A couple of papers that weren't too bad and were made into somewhat interesting assignments like policy memos.

comments.course: I would highly recommend this course. Learn a lot of useful analytical skills. Course is relevant for everyone whether you are pre-med, interested in health policy, or just interested in the class, since we are all consumers of health care.
